segments.text: 1.30 with Professor Willis Pequenot, P-E-Q-U-E-G-N-O-T.
Present interview, Robert Calvert and Professor Pequenot.

Professor Pecklenaut, what we would like to know is what took you to Berkeley in 36 as a science major, where I understand you stayed through a PhD in 42, and what direction or what influence led you to a degree in what appears to be environmental science?
Yes.
I went to Berkeley in 36.
I left Berkeley actually in 36 as a result of the fact that
They had established a marine science program at La Jolla, California, as a matter of fact, around the turn of the century.
By the time I went there, it was very well known, and it was beginning to be called Scripps Institution of Oceanography.
But actually, it was the zoology department of Berkeley that established this laboratory.
I had come to know some of the men who were on the staff at Berkeley.
And I thought they were excellent people, and so I went up there to study with them.
While there, I had always at that time to keep in mind where one could get a job, because the Depression was still having an effect in California.
And so I drifted into other departments.
I took some work in agriculture.
I did some work in soil chemistry to prepare myself for that civil service area.
I took work in vertebrate zoology, marine zoology.
And so the University of California had no major for me.
And as a consequence, they created one, which they called environmental science.
And thus, I got the first degree that they ever had.
And maybe they haven't had another one since of this type.
Actually, I was going to stay on.

and I have to correct one point on your statement, at Berkeley for a Ph.D., but it happened that a teaching fellowship opened up at UCLA, and they were just then, in 1937, given the authorization to grant Ph.D.s in zoological science.
So I...
They offered me a teaching fellowship down there.

And I was advised by the head of the department at Berkeley that these were very hard to come by, and it might be a good idea to go down there for a master's, particularly since I could study with Loy Holmes Miller, who had been a member of the Science Party on the Albatross, which had made
an oceanographic cruise all through the Gulf of Mexico and in the Pacific region.
And so I went down to work with Loy Holmes Miller in 37, and it became very evident that I might be the only PhD he would ever have since he was approaching retirement.
He was head of the zoology department down there.
And for many other reasons, I decided to stay on.
So I got both my master's and PhD at the University of California, Los Angeles.
At that time, UCLA was the parent institution for Scripps Institution of Oceanography.
And as a consequence of this, we had men coming from Scripps to teach courses in
marine science, and I became an assistant to Martin Johnson, who was a zooplankton specialist at the Scripps Institution at the time.
Also, Sverdrup was then director.
He came up.
I got to know him very well.
Roger Rebell was then working his way up gradually.
I had first met Roger Rebell when he was a geologist at Scripps back in 32, I think.
And so it was just a natural event that I became more and more interested in marine aspects of biological science.
And at the same time, I
became the assistant to Professor George McGinnity of Caltech, who also came to, he was one of the foremost marine ecologists.
He came to offer coursework.
And it's my interest in marine science why it was natural that I would become his assistant.
As a result of all these things, I
decided that this might be the thing for me to specialize in.
In 1940, I was invited to go to Pomona College as an instructor.
And they had a marine laboratory at Laguna Beach, California, which had been established
Soon after, University of California at Berkeley had established their marine laboratory at .
Pardon me.
Can we do something?
I don't know if the secretary has gone or not.
Sure.
Hello?
And so I began teaching courses in marine ecology and marine invertebrates in the summer of 1940, which I continued at Laguna Beach.
until 1946 when I went to the University of Chicago for a time in 47.
And then came back and was invited to teach at the California Institute of Technology Marine Laboratory at Corona del Mar.
Meanwhile, I kept associations with people at Scripps.
And in 55, I went on to become a research associate down there
while I was on leave and also a consultant to a large vitamin corporation who were interested in developing natural vitamins from marine organisms.
And at that time, I went to Europe for these people to get a large oceanographic vessel built.
somewhere in Europe, finally ended up in Germany after long excursions through Holland and Scandinavian countries and so on.
So that I kept this activity going until 1960 when I went to the National Science Foundation and then was invited by people here
to come to become an oceanographer in the Gulf of Mexico region.
I had never thought of really calling myself an oceanographer, actually.
And when I came here, I found that there was no knowledge of the deep ocean in the Gulf, and so I began to specialize in that.
And we're just completing the first major report on that, and I'm preparing a book on
the deep aspects of the Gulf of Mexico.
So that's a quick run through that.
I came here in 1963.
Meanwhile, I had gone to, for very short periods of time, I became head of the Department of
biology with particular interest in marine science at State University of New York at Stony Brook.
I resigned in protest there because they had fired the president, so I didn't stay very long.
I went back to NSF.
Oh, was this 62, 63?
Yeah.
Okay.
Yeah.
It's an interval in there that I don't like to remember because it looked like such a promising thing.

They were getting ready to establish a major marine installation on Long Island Sound, but I felt that they had unfairly fired the president and appealed to Nelson Rockefeller, and he turned the appeal down.
But some years later, he admitted he had been misadvised and
He made reparations to the president, who had left, of course, and wrote letters of apology to most of us who had protested.
But it was too late then.
I wasn't going back anyway.
What was he fired?
For what was he fired?
Presumably for being relatively incompetent in terms of

the future development of the university, that he was attempting to do it much too fast, that he wasn't an orderly individual, while he was a statistical thermodynamicist and he was loaded with intellect, so there was no problem.
It was just internal jealousy.
After I came here,
I found this was a little bit of a problem area.
There was a good deal of dissension in the department.
And since I was the newest member, I was asked to be acting head of the Department of Oceanography and Meteorology for presumably six months by Rutter.
I had come here to get away from the administration.
If I'd wanted that, I could have stayed at NSF.
But Earl Rutter, who was then president,
insisted, really, that I do this as a very personal favor for six months when it lasted for two and a half years, which was... Well, we have it 63-64.
Well, I actually can't remember now.
I think it was till 66.
I think I left it in July of 66, whenever Dick Geyer came.
I think he came in 66.
In 66.
True.
Then you didn't come specifically to build the Department of Oceanography here at A&A?
No, I did not.
I came to really develop ocean-going biological oceanography because when I came there was one microscope in the Department for Biological Use.
Al Syed had been here working on a project on the Mississippi Delta
At the time, he had not started with the Antarctic.
Macken had been the biological oceanographer, and apparently he had left with some kind of ill feelings going on.
And as a matter of course, whether he took things to biology or not, I don't know.
But at any rate, there was nothing here to work with, so we had to sort of build things up a little bit.
But meanwhile, the Alaminos arrived, and under the
the guidance of Hugh McClellan, the Alaminas was outfitted as a research vessel.
John Lyman was then head of the oceanography program at NSF, and it provided, I think, roughly a million dollars for the job.
And I think that Dr. McClellan, who's a physical oceanographer now with Sea Grant, did really an excellent job of
refitting that vessel.
As a matter of fact, I personally feel it's a much better vessel than the gyre.
I don't know whether you say these things or not, but I really think it was one of the nicer ocean-going vessels.
It had its problems, but it certainly was a good oceanographic vessel.
But as always, remember that oceanography, prior to the
Second World War was wholly physical oceanography.
There were some geological aspects to be sure, but including that as a physical fact.
So that people such as Martin Johnson, who was then at Scripps, had to fight for every day they got aboard a ship in order to sample.
And as a consequence of this,
I think that most ships were outfitted for physical activities and not for biological activities.
If I had been here a year sooner, it could have been modified because I became a very, well, McClellan and I became good friends and he was willing to listen, but it was too late to modify.
Now, when you speak of being outfitted for physical versus marine, exactly what do you mean?
No, marine biological.
Well, there are many things that biologists need.
They need much more workspace on the aft section of a vessel.
Most of the equipment had to go over on the starboard forward quarter of the vessel.
whereas it would have been much nicer had we been able to put things over directly from the stern.
As it was, I had to fairly lead cables along the side of the vessel at great distances.
Of course, when I was working in the deep water, as deep as I could go, and furthermore, you see, we should have had a bigger winch.
They only had 30,000 feet of 7-16ths cable on the vessel.
It would have been nice if we'd had 40,000.
and probably gone to half-inch cable, we could have reached deeper aspects of the Caribbean.
But we had five or six miles of wire out, obviously, when we were dredging the bottom.
Of course, it's the basis now.
That collection is the basis for the systematic collection in this department, which my wife is now curating, fortunately.
But I have it scattered from the air base to private storage to this area, plus the collection.
And it'll be some years before it's completed.
When the first work was done in the Gulf of Mexico by Louis Agassiz aboard the Blake, he had 70 people to aid him
in the small deep sea collection that he put together.
And we've had on the average of two or three.
And we've had a collection perhaps 75 to 100 times the size of his.
So we've had a little go.
But we have just put out a major report on the upper continental slope of the northern Gulf of Mexico.
And as I say, I'm deep in the manuscript now of one that will cover the abyssal aspects of the Gulf of Mexico and northern Caribbean.
Is this all encompassing now?
Does that cover all the species that you're finding or are you restricted to certain types, certain sizes?
No, the work that we're doing is total.
In other words, we have
What we've done on the currents, what we have done as biologists on the sedimentology, what we have done from fishes to sponges.
So it is all encompassing.
We're trying to create an ecosystem approach, ecosystem analysis as well.
So it is a thoroughgoing ecological look at this.
We are not able to quantitate as we would like to, but we do have a quasi
quantitation in, you know, we know roughly the size of these dredges we've been using, or trawls.
I used a trawl that was 20 meters, had a 20 meter gape, and had Chinese V-boards that weighed about 750 pounds apiece.
And the net itself was about 30 meters long, so it was a gigantic thing to handle, you know, in deep water.
But we managed to do it.
Deep water sampling is a little bit trying because it takes perhaps an hour and a half to get the trawl on the bottom and may take as long to bring it back up.
As a matter of fact, I got it caught on some rocks in the deep aspect of the Columbian Basin in the Caribbean.
all but about 300 feet of wire out, and I was caught on the bottom.
And the profiler, the precision depth recorder profile, showed that I was hooked on the rock wall of this basin.
And it took me eight hours to release it.
I didn't leave the winch control forward, and I had to pull the ship backwards all the time, because my winch
was more powerful than the ship.
And so I could stop the ship, and with that thing caught on this gigantic wall, which was, oh, I don't know, it must have been 8,000 or 9,000 feet high.
The water was about 14,000 feet there deep, I think.
Well, I worked eight hours, and of course that's in the trade winds.
I had to keep pulling the ship back against these steady swells coming in,
And the swells would break on the aft end of the vessel, and it was 180 feet long, and that thing would come flying clear on over.
Spray would fly clear over onto the bridge.
So I never had a friendly word with the captain after that day.
But at any rate, I got it off, and interestingly enough, it had three new species of animals in it.
And it had rocks which had never been seen in the Caribbean before, and for which several expeditions had gone there to find, costing hundreds of thousands of dollars.
And in this one accident, we got that set of rocks.
We published a short paper on it, but others have gone down there now and have taken those samples.
Well, do we have a breather to see where we're going?
Oh, we know where we're going.
Do you consider yourself a generalist rather than a specialist?
I was reading your publication list.
This possibly answers part of the question.
Yes, well, I think my broad background does explain some interests.
You see, I started out, actually started out getting an interest in biological things because of the fact that
I traveled with a group of students led by a biologically inclined professor in Riverside on the desert for at least three years.
And I got to the point where I knew every shrub and animal on the desert.
So this was in the period from about 29 to 33, somewhere in there.
Then, when I went to UCLA, I decided that I needed to get some terrestrial biology, so I studied the biology of an entire mountain range.
Was that when you were a ranger in 39?
No.
That was as a result of that work, I was invited by the Park Service to become a trainee to take a position with the National Park Service in Washington.
And they wanted me to start
by going first to Yosemite National Park and then to Lassen Volcanic to learn both the biological and the physical, since Lassen, of course, was then still considered an active volcano.
But as a result of these things, I was very fortunate.
I took ornithology with one of the really great ornithologists
of the West, Joseph Grinnell.
I took plant physiology with one of the great plant physiologists of his time at Berkeley.
And I took genetics with men that were foremost and was even invited to be an assistant to Theodosius Dobzhansky, who just died, who was one of the leading geneticists
from Columbia University and then to Caltech.
I met Thomas Hunt Morgan, who was one of the really important geneticists who introduced Drosophila fruit fly as the genetics vehicle.
I became very good friends with George Beadle, who Beadle and Tatum were the first ones to do the
one gene, one enzyme, one gene theory for which they got the Nobel Prize.
And I'm not bragging about it, but it just happened.
These people fell into my life, and they inspired me to read very broadly in biological science.
And as a consequence of these experiences,
have had to become a generalist.
I've been interested in anything that would fit into a better understanding of the machinery that drives the natural systems.
So I think that this also started through one course, and I sometimes
do feel that students can be inspired by a course, although many of them feel no longer this kind of feeling.
I took a course in the history of science at Berkeley.
And that course, which drew specialists from all over the country to lecture in their areas, whether it be medicine, pharmacology, biology, physics, whatever,
was one of the most inspiring courses I ever took.
Now, the book itself was also that way.
Obviously, if you're tracing the history of science, you realize how general the people were.
Certainly, Aristotle is the epitome of that.
But even coming up after the Renaissance, you've got the generalist.
And of course, analytical specialist
so much in sway when I was going to university.
But it was in the 40s that people began to realize that analytical approach to science was no longer going to work.
And it was for this reason in the biological area that ecology came into its own.
There are still people here who debate whether ecology is a science.
They just don't have any
a fundamental knowledge of intellectuality when they asked that question.
Synthesis became the word beginning in the 40s.
At the same time, there were those who were working not only in molecular biology, but beginning at Caltech to work in sub-molecular biology.

Now it was because of George Beadle, who was then chairman of the biological division of Caltech, that Crick and Watson came to Caltech and synthesized their knowledge to get an insight into DNA, which of course set genetics off in a whole new area.
So that was about the 52 period, 53 period in there.
George Beadle's still alive.
You know, he went to become president of the University of Chicago.
He's now doing, still doing interesting work in genetics on corn, which turns out to be an exciting vehicle to study.
It doesn't seem like it would be, but genetics of corn takes you all over, you know, because obviously it's
I'm going to not comment on that.
That's getting out of oceanography.
One quick question.
Do you think that oceanographers are more inclined to be generalists than, let's say, specialists?
Yes, I feel so.
And I feel this is very natural.
We are still following what was laid down in scripts years ago as to the curriculum in the early years.
And this by its very nature indicates that if you're going to understand the ocean as a system, you've got to know something about all aspects of the ocean.
The answer, therefore, is that those who have come through the oceanographic curriculum generally are more inclined to a broad view.
Those who have come from engineering, however, tend to be highly specialized.
And we see this in this department, even.
And you see it almost in every major institution where engineers have entered the field.
So that I would say, though, that those who go through oceanography as a curriculum tend to be much broader in their perspective than those who've entered from a single discipline.
Just happened, my training was very broad.
And so it was natural that I should come there.
But I put out a little paper on currents because I couldn't find anybody who would know anything about the currents in the bottom.
The time I wrote that paper, there weren't many who believed there were any currents in the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico.
Here, for example, I did something with geology because I needed to know something about that aspect.
Go ahead with your question, maybe.
No, I'm fine.
